dataset.title: Coarse woody debris density and nutrient data with age determined using the Chronosequence method

address.deliveryPoint: Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
Oregon State University;College of Forestry;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall

section.para: This data set is used to document the changes in external characteristics, density, nutrient content, and form of carbon associated with various decay classes and ages of logs and snags. The pieces that have been dated form the basis for a chronosequence. All the pieces sampled are used to define the characterictics of decay classes. These classes are used in turn to convert the external dimension data in TD12 to estimates of mass and nutrient stores.

additionalInfo.para: Bole Decomposition Rates of Seventeen Tree Species in Western U.S.A. http://www.fsl.orst.edu/lter/pubs/webdocs/reports/decomp/cwd_decomp_web.htm This dataset related to a number of other large data sets. For most site descriptions of the living forest can be found in the TV10 files. Dead tree inventories are found in the TD12 files. There are other similar sets of data that have been collected by Sollins, and Graham in the Pacific Northwest region. Logs and snags were often sampled within or near permanent plots. Some of the logs at Sequoia National Park were tagged and mapped for relocation.

intellectualRights.para: <section><title>Data Use Agreement</title><para> Any Forest science data Bank (FSDB) data set and accompanying metadata available on these web pages can be downloaded for academic, research, recreational, and other professional purposes. Permission to download data sets is granted to the Data User without a fee subject to the following terms. The Data User will: </para><para><itemizedlist><listitem><para> notify the designated contact (e.g., Principle Investigator or Data Set Contact) when any derivative work based on or derived from the data and documentation is distributed; </para></listitem><listitem><para> notify users that such derivative work is a modified version and not the original data and documentation distributed by the FSDB;</para></listitem><listitem><para> not redistribute original data and documentation; </para></listitem><listitem><para> acknowledge the support of the Forest Science data Bank in any publications using these data and documentation. (See general acknowledgement below and see web page for specific data citation for each study data set); </para></listitem><listitem><para> send two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the data and documentation to the following address: Andrews Experimental Forest LTER Program, c/o Don Henshaw, Forestry Sciences Lab, 3200 SW Jefferson Way, Corvallis, OR 97331</para></listitem></itemizedlist><para> By using or copying these data and documentation, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. The Forest Science Data Bank shall have the right to terminate this agreement immediately by written notice upon the Data User’s breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. The Data User may be held responsible for any misuse that is caused or encouraged by the Data User’s failure to abide by the terms of this agreement. Thank you for your cooperation. We hope your collaboration with our site is a productive one!</para><para> Disclaimer: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "AS IS". The Forest Science Data Bank shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of data sets.</para><para> General acknowledgement: Data sets were provided by the Forest Science Data Bank, a partnership between the Department of Forest Science, Oregon State University, and the U.S. Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Corvallis, Oregon. </para></section>

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Sequoia National Park , Fraser Experimental Forest, Puerto Morelos, Quintana Roo, Mexico, Cascade Head Experimental Forest, Pringle Falls Experimental Forest, Los Tuxtlas Experimental forest.

changeHistory.changeScope: The data were started to be collected in 1982. The current files were started in 1990 as part of an effort to make collection of this type of data systematic. The abstract will need to be updated as new sites are added to the files.
Removed data access restriction per request of metadata contact person.
Non-critical update to test new EML generating program and prepare EML for congruency checker test

address.deliveryPoint: US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station
Oregon State University;College of Forestry;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
Forest Ecosystems and Society Department in Forestry

description.para: Sites in Rocky Mountains, Pacific Northwest, Mexico; specifically Sequoia National Park, Fraser Experimental National Park, Puerto Morelos, Quintana Roo, Mexico. http://www.fsl.orst.edu/lter/pubs/webdocs/reports/decomp/study_areas.htm

samplingDescription.para: The Chronosequence method involves finding woody debris of varying decay classes with known time since death. A "cookie" sample is removed from each log and each tissue is measured to obtain tissue density.

abstract.para:
The H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest is a living laboratory that provides unparalleled opportunities for the study of forest and stream ecosystems in the central Cascade Range of Oregon. Since 1980, as a part of the National Science Foundation Long Term Ecological Research (NSF-LTER) program, the Andrews Experimental Forest has become a leader in the analysis of forest and stream ecosystem dynamics.

Long-term field experiments and measurement programs have focused on climate dynamics, streamflow, water quality, and vegetation succession. Currently researchers are working to develop concepts and tools needed to predict effects of natural disturbance, land use, and climate change on ecosystem structure, function, and species composition.

The Andrews Experimental Forest is administered cooperatively by the USDA Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Oregon State University and the Willamette National Forest. Funding for the research program comes from the National Science Foundation (NSF), US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Oregon State University, and other sources.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Arbitrary site number associated with cwd piece.

textDomain.definition: Arbitrary site number associated with cwd piece.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year the sample collection took place
Month the sample collection took place
Day the sample collection took place
Number of CWD piece
Species of the log, snag or stump

codeDefinition.definition: Unknown due to extent of decay

attribute.attributeDefinition: Position of the log, snag, or stump.

codeDefinition.definition: Snag; indicates piece was standing dead
Stump; indicates a lower portion of a tree left after tree was harvested

attribute.attributeDefinition: Decay class of sample

codeDefinition.definition: Freshly killed; sound log with fine twigs present
Beginning to decompose; twigs falling off; bark cover intact
Partially decayed;bark and sapwood sloughing off; many brnaches have fallen Off
Very decayed; unable to support itself; branch stubs can be moved by hand id Icating Wood Decayed To Center.
Extremely decayed; cross-section elliptical; embedded in forest floor; wood Structure Largely Gone

attribute.attributeDefinition: Residence time of the cwd piece; the time it has been dead
Method of determining the residence time

codeDefinition.definition: Decomposition time estimate is based on visual foliage appearance: Freshly Killed Needles Still Green Or Red-brown
Dated from a seedling on a nurse log.
Palm, by counting annual rings since hit by a log
Dated from a record in a permanent plot.
Dated from a fall scar on a living or recently killed tree.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Cause of death; this is very general

codeDefinition.definition: Tree was cut down as in a thinning operation
Fire; could be based on record or fire scar (latter is less reliable)
Other form of mortality including unknown causes
Wind throw with the root system tore out of ground

attribute.attributeDefinition: Diameter at breast height of the cwd piece. in cases of very decayed piece this is estimated. used to calculate the original volume and mass
Diameter at base of the cwd piece. this is the current measurement and does not correct for fragmentation. used to claculate the current volume& mass
Diameter at top of the cwd piece. this is the current measurement and does not correct for fragmentation. used to claculate the current volume& mass
Length of the cwd piece. this includes zones that have decayed away but not spaces caused when the piece fell to the forest floor.
Bark cover on the bole of the cwd piece.
Volume missing. accounts for parts that have decayed away and do not co ntribute to the current volume (except parts missing to non-decay process).
Diamter at first sample point.
Height at first sample point.
Diameter at second sample point.
Height at second sample point.
Diameter at third sample point.
Height at third sample point.
Diameter at fourth sample point.
Height at fourth sample point.
Diameter at fifth sample point.
Height at fifth sample point.
Current volume of the CWD piece
Initial volume of the cwd piece

attribute.attributeDefinition: Tissue type of the sample

codeDefinition.definition: Bark; indicates inner and outer bark were measured together

attribute.attributeDefinition: Thickness of the sample, may not be recorded if water displacement used to measure the volume.
Area of the sample, may not be recorded if water displacement used to measure the volume.
Volume of the sample, if based on water displacement then thickness and area will be missing. samples soaked 24-48 hrs before displacement measurement
Usually dry weight of subsample (a wedge), usually after 4-7 days at 55 C.
Usually wet weight of subsample (a wedge), may be missing if water displacement used to measure the volume
Density of sample; calculated from dry weight divided by fresh volume. usually total dry weight divided by the volume of a cross-section
Moisture content of subsample; calculated as water weight lost during drying divided by the dry weight.
Total wet weight of the sample (entire cross-section) measured in the field
Total dry weight of the sample (entire cross-section) calc-ted from total wet weight and ratio between subsample dry and wet wghts

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year the sample collection took place
Month the sample collection took place
Day the sample collection took place
Number of CWD piece
Is foliage (leaves or needles) present? y=yes n=no
Are twigs present?
Are branches present?
Is bark still on the branches?
Is bark still on the bole?
Is sapwood sloughing off the bole?
Is the log collasping and unable to support its own weight?
Is the log scattered over surface and ellpitical in cross-section?
Are there fungal conks present?
Is there moss cover present?
Is there lichen cover present?
Is there evidence of carpenter ants present? best evidence is from cutting into the log
Is there evidence of termites present? best evidence is from cutting into the log
Is there evidence of bark beetles present? best evidence is from underside of bark or wood surface of the log
Is there evidence of bears have been ripping open logs?
Is there cubical brown rot present?
Is there white rot present?
Is the sapwood friable? crushed by hand?
Is the heartwood friable? crushed by hand?
Is there casehardening of the outer wood? wood takes on a bleached look and is solid
Can you move the branch subs sticking out of the log by hand? this indicates wood is rotten to the center
Woodborers present?

ns2:unit.name: number of years
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one year excluding leap seconds and leap days, 31536000 seconds (often used for age in years)
